review_title: Institute of Health Professions at Mass General
pros: Talented faculty and staff, dedicated students, lovely campus by the waterfront at the Charlestown Navy Yard, supportive faculty administration, a focus on teaching students to work as effective teams, service to the community, and successful research programs
cons: It's a very welcoming and inclusive campus and everyone has been kind and collaborative

review_title: Fiscally Irresponsible, Unorganized, Lack of Equity
pros: - If you find the right department there are good coworkers - Work-life balance - Smart and fairly paid faculty
cons: - laid off 20 staff all at once in 2023 due to poor business decisions by management and academic units. - hired expensive external consultants to do the important thinking. - poor business sense in the upper crust of the institution. Lacks qualifications to run a multimillion dollar institution. - revolving door for leadership roles. Deans turned over quickly and searches took forever. - poorly resourced HR with big turn over. - below average pay for staff. - staff not seen as integral to the educational mission. -lack of equity when it comes to dispersment of budget$$ and resources

review_title: Very good company to work for
pros: Hybrid work environment as well as great team
cons: They hired a lot of people during the pandemic, and now most of them do not have jobs

pros: Good student job! Vanessa is the best manager a grad student could ask for!!!
cons: Lot of onboarding for a “easy” job.

pros: There are labs that do very exciting works. Overall experience depends on whom you end up working with as a postdoc and how you get along with teammates. good opportunity to know more people and maybe have more collaboration in your CV. very nice transportation service offered to employees
cons: I am not sure covid situation made it worst but I have been working as postdocs in several different universities in North America and I do have very mixed feelings about this place. I feel the research space and equipment have not been maintained overall impeccably tidy and clean by researchers and people who work either temporary or permanent for many years. The salary is low. The quality of food served in the cafeteria is also not impressive.

review_title: “A million girls would kill for this job” 🙄

cons:
“You are the best of the best”
“You are heroes”
“Sorry, you can’t have a union”
“25 years of service? Your number in line for a monthly parking spot in a garage is 457826!”

review_title: MGH Institute of Health Professions -- Low Pay, but Otherwise Great Place to Work and Teach.
pros:
The environment is stimulating intellectually
Across the board there is appreciation for our teaching and for our role in mentoring students.
The relationship with Mass General Hospital allows for research and clinical contacts.
The Institute employs and makes available advanced uses of teaching technologies (simulations, distance learning platform, et cetera).
The social environment is supportive and upbeat.
The benefits package is strong.
cons:
The pay is low -- I have worked there 16 years, brought in the largest federal grant that has flowed through the Institute, and my pay, after deductions for taxes and benefits is $55K.
Historically  management has not received 360 degree evaluations, just top-down from the President, but the new president has listened to the faculty and has announced that bottom-up evaluations will be incorporated moving forward.

pros:
-Wonderful, intelligent, thoughtful, creative colleagues
-Smaller teams/ departments 
-Networking potential is endless
- Location is beautiful 
- Associated with top hospitals throughout Boston
- Interprofessional Collaboration is promoted and encouraged.
- Partners Health Shuttle
- Monthly "wine and cheese" celebrations which are inclusive and fun.

I consider myself fortunate to have worked with so many inspiring people. I learned more than I ever could have anticipated during my time at the Institute and I take with me both personal and professional relationships that I consider invaluable and imperative to my future.
cons:
-Higher administration is slow to encourage creative innovations. 
- No direct subway access, however free shuttle service available.

review_title: Faculty Perspectives on MGH Institute of Health Professions
pros:
Strong collegial support
Robust commitment to, and value placed on, teaching
Meritocracy
Openness to new ideas & solutions
Vibrant and growing 
High standards and expectations for achievement
Commitment to technology-savvy education
Extraordinarily strong physical therapy and speech-language pathology programs given that the MGH Institute of Health Professions does not yet support a PhD program.
cons:
Small endowment results in over-dependence on tuition, larger class sizes, more work for instructors

Small endowment also results in small  number of scholarships to draw under-represented minorites, which are greatly needed in the health professions.

review_title: Worst experience to work with manager ever ever
pros: Summer Friday's, winter break, more than 3 week vacation, snow day, 401k contribution and pension plan as far as the reason that keep me to stay and tolerate.
cons: Too much politics, favoritism, worst communication between staff and manager.  Watch out this org Without peer review, just manager review your performance, if you don't look good to their eyes, you'll be dead for sure.  management is the worst. Bossy, selfish and aggressive to staff

pros: As an intern, every full-time staff member was very eager to insure that my experience was educational and formative. The researchers are hard working and are as intent on educating others as they are on completing their personal projects.
cons: There were no Cons in my experience. Our office seemed very quiet at times, but this was helpful in an environment where individual work and focus are of primary importance.

review_title: the MGH Institute of Health Professions suffers from bad administration
pros: Faculty are genuinely nice and collegial.
cons: Administration in the past two years have undermined the wonderful work environment but deception. self-serving agendas, and refusing to acknowledge the stresses that our rapid growth has produced.  Admin is being driven by lust for profit, regardless of what happens to the people.

pros: Time off and benefits through Partners HealthCare. HR department is helpful and strives to innovate. Overall the IHP has a great sense of community.
cons: Lack of interdepartmental communication and workflows hinders projects. There is little room for staff to have a voice and hand in decision making.

pros: Coworkers very friendly and competent, good resources, access to lots of professional development activities in Boston, got to know more staff and professors as a GA during school there
cons: had to graduate and start the profession I trained for
